speakeroldname: Hon. Gilles Loiselle (President of the TVeasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
subsubtopic: MAIN ESTIMATES, 1992-93 EXPLANATORY STATEMENT BY PRESIDENT OF THE TREASURY BOARD
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased today to table in the House the government's Main Estimates for the 1992-93 fiscal year. I believe that these estimates attest to the government's ongoing efforts to make its operations more efficient, to reduce costs and to maintain a fair balance between the demand for federal services and the taxpayers' ability to pay.
The Main Estimates explain in detail how the government plans to spend $159.6 billion, the planned budgetary expenditures for 1992-93, pursuant to the announcement made this week by my colleague, the Minister of Finance.
In presenting this budget the government wishes to obtain authorization to spend $48.8 billion from Parliament. The rest is covered in legislative authority already granted by Parliament.
Cast year I made explicit commitments in the House. Today I wish to report on our achievements over the past year and on the measures that we have taken and are now taking to cut spending and obtain the most value from each taxpayer dollar.
I will also tell you, Mr. Speaker, about our commitment to provide Canadians with the best services possible, what we are doing, and the plans we are making to meet this commitment.
The spending control plan that we introduced with the 1990 budget and that we later broadened and expanded in the 1991 budget affected many programs. The growth of most programs, except for equity programs and those that meet Canadians' basic social needs, has been slowed, while other programs have been frozen, reduced or simply eliminated.
Routine Proceedings
Spending control has forced departments and agencies to face increasing demands with fewer resources. The freeze or reduction of operating and maintenance budgets has been an important element of the cost cutting measures in all budgets since 1985. Since that year the real value of operating and maintenance budgets for programs in place has gone down by about 30 per cent as a result of these and other measures.

In keeping with the 1991 budget, the government limited salary increases to zero and three per cent over two years when Parliament passed the Public Sector Compensation Act in October 1991. We have also reduced to three the number of management layers below the deputy minister level. This makes the management structure in the federal Public Service comparable to that of many large organizations in the private sector which have had to restructure their operations to reduce costs.
We are ahead of schedule on the commitment made in last year's budget to reduce the number of senior managers by 10 per cent within two years. There are now 4,430 members of the executive group, down 320 from January 1991.
Our record is there for all to see. It is a record of performance, not words. We have reduced appreciably the rate of growth of program spending. In 1984 program spending represented nearly 20 per cent of the country's Gross Domestic Product. Today, mostly because of the restraint measures we have introduced, the figure is down to 16.7 per cent.
The savings we have made in recent years have not come only from reducing the payments we make to individual Canadians and the transfers we make to the provinces. The deepest cuts were made in government operations and capital. Canadians have indicated that they want governments to spend less, to spend smarter and to be more efficient. We continue to scrutinize expenditures to ensure that we spend only where Canadians need and want to receive services.
Programs including grants and contributions are being reduced in a number of areas. Defence spending is being scaled back further. Funding for new social housing will continue to grow but at a more limited pace. We remain

Routine Proceedings
committed to the green plan spending of $3 billion over six years, but we will delay some of the spending for two years. We are improving the management of the Canada Student Loans Program. These actions will yield savings of $530 million in 1992-93 and $3.4 billion over five years.
We are continuing to restrain the cost of government operations. Departmental non-salary operating budgets are being reduced by a further 3 per cent. The 20 per cent restriction or reduction on travel outside Canada introduced in December 1989 will be continued.
The number of international meetings and the size of foreign delegations will be scaled back. Ministers, members of Parliament and deputy ministers will no longer be entitled to travel first class. Business class travel will be reduced as will be the amount spent on hotel accommodations.
The government Leader in the Senate, the Hon. Lowell Murray will be reviewing spending in the communications function to identify $75 million in expenditure reduction.
Forty-six separate organizations will be wound up, privatized or consolidated with other organizations. Thirteen ministerial advisory councils will be brought to an end. Three new agencies will be put on hold, and a number of activities will be privatized.
Cost recovery will be extended to a number of additional program areas, continuing to shift the cost of providing specific services to the beneficiaries and away from general taxpayers.
Assets no longer required will be sold. The government will increase its effort to collect unpaid debts.
These measures, taken together, will provide savings in excess of $1 billion in 1992-93 and $7.3 billion over the next five years.
The changes we are making in the way we do things address squarely the twin challenges of restraint and serving Canadians in the best way possible. We must balance clients' demands for services with taxpayers' ability to pay.
We are not simply cutting. We are restructuring to make our services more accessible to Canadians. We recognize that due to the expenditure cuts announced this week, reductions in the level of some services may occur. We want to minimize these effects by shifting
resources from internal administration to the points of service delivery.
In 1992-93 the government plans to spend $159.6 billion and that is $119.4 billion in programs with the remaining $40.2 billion going to servicing the public debt.
Out of every dollar spent, over 27 cents is transferred directly to individuals through such things as pensions and unemployment insurance benefits.
Transfers to the provinces and the territories made up principally of equalization programs payments to the less well-off provinces and payments to help fund provincial and territorial programs such as health care, post-secondary education and social assistance take up another 16 cents.
About 8 cents go to defence, another 10 cents to industrial and regional support transfers to aboriginal people and international assistance.
Subsidies to Crown corporations take up 3 cents. The cost of servicing the debt accounts for another 25 cents. The remaining 11 cents represent the cost of providing services directly to Canadians. This is made up mainly of employees' wages and salaries, accommodation, equipment, travel and related expenses.
In 1984 Canadians were paying $1 in taxes and getting $1.33 in program benefits. The difference was financed by borrowed money, so payment was put off to the future. The future is now.
Today, Canadians are still paying their tax dollar, but a growing share is being used to pay interest on the debt accumulated through past spending.
This is why we must continue to hold the fiscal course that this government has charted since 1984.

Restraint measures have forced managers and agencies to meet an increased demand for services with fewer resources. Nevertheless, they did not falter. Aware that restrictions are here to stay, they are determined to meet the challege head-on.
They remain steadfast in their determination to serve. Like their counterparts in the private sector, they take pride in ensuring that taxpayers get their money's worth.
Dedicated federal public servants are responsible for providing Canadians with the kind of efficient service they expect from their government. Canadians are demanding, and they have every right to be. The government's employees are doing a good job.
February 27, 1992

We are decentralizing decision-making. We are giving public servants the authority to make decisions and making them accountable for those decisions. They are also responsible for getting results.
Many of our recent initiatives were inspired by the wide-ranging renewal announced by the Prime Minister in December 1989-Public Service 2000. Creating special service agencies will make public servants better able to run their agency like a business. Operating budgets will give them a chance to determine the most effective distribution of funding and resources.
We will privatize services and functions if this option turns out to be less costly and more effective and improves service to the public. We will continue to charge user fees for activities that mostly benefit specific clients or users.
Our government is committed to providing the best possible service with the resources available, and to do so courteously and efficiently. It is committed to creating a Public Service whose employees have an abiding concern for the public, are sensitive to the public's needs, and are capable of solving problems and responding quickly to the needs of Canadians. We continue to restructure the public administration in order to streamline its services and facilitate their access.
The departments will co-operate in order to better answer the needs of their clients, and they will take all reasonable measures to logically group together government services in a single service area. They will consult with their clients, so that the latter can help them resolve important issues. They will have more flexible hours, so as to better meet the needs of their clients. They will reduce the number of forms and revise them to make them easier to fill. They will have a single registration number for businesses. They will use electronic devices for their procurements, and they will invest in training as well as in new technologies.
In order to make other savings and increase efficiency, the government will continue to give up activities that can be performed elsewhere at a reduced cost. It will continue to privatize services or to enter into partnerships with the private sector, when such measures are financially profitable. The government will also continue to divest itself of excess goods, to recover its costs and to
Routine Proceedings
insist on results whenever possible. It will continue to examine regulations in order to determine if they are still useful and, when they are, to ensure that they do not go against efficiency and competitiveness. It will also simplify those regulations where possible. We will examine the needs of small organizations and determine if they can share their office space in order to improve service and reduce costs. The government will continue to ensure a greater efficiency in markets and procurements, and to deregulate operations within the Public Service as operating budgets will come into effect.

In conclusion, the measures announced this week build on the actions we have taken over the last seven years. They demonstrate our commitment to sound fiscal management, to reducing the demand on the taxpayers dollars and to placing more resources where employees serve the public directly. That is where Canadians want us to place the focus, and that is where it should be. In this way we can keep costs down while making sure that we provide the best possible services.

subsubtopic: MAIN ESTIMATES, 1992-93 EXPLANATORY STATEMENT BY PRESIDENT OF THE TREASURY BOARD
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in listening to the budget on Tuesday and listening to the President of Treasury Board today, one might have thought that at this point in time we would have heard something about what the government was going to do for the unemployed.
We may have thought we would have heard something about what was happening with the primary resource sector as a result of the over-valued Canadian dollar. We might even have had a better insight into how the Government of Canada intended to spend $160 billion for the benefit of Canadians who are most in need.
Canadians might have been looking forward to some answers on whether or not the government was prepared to become involved in renewing municipal infrastructure in this country. I think that the bottom line after the last couple of days is that Canadians are asking themselves what happened to the government and members of government who, not very long ago, talked about jobs, jobs, jobs and talked about the fact that they were the people who could best manage the affairs of the country.

Routine Proceedings
All that has gone for naught, and now we are faced with having to deal with documents and estimates. Just to set the discussion in perspective, this is one budget document. This is the document that represents the
1992-93 estimates for employment and immigration in Canada.
In this document one would take a look and find that employment and immigration is going to spend substantially less this year than last year. It will be quite a reduction. If you look at it closely, there will be an increase in the number of people who will be working for employment and immigration. There will be some 1,200 more people than were involved last year. There will be less money and more people.
One wonders what the people are for. Are they to check up on people who are collecting unemployment insurance? Are they to deal with matters that are going to help the Canadians who need help, or are they there simply to create more problems? It is very difficult to tell. One of the things that we will never be able to determine as Canadians, as taxpayers or as parliamentarians is really what is in the estimates of the government.
This represents one of over 90 books that were tabled this morning figuratively by the minister. He did not bring them all into the Chamber, but they are around for anyone who wants to look at them. There are 90 publications-some of them thicker than this one; some of them are thinner- covering all kinds of government activity, on how it is going to spend $160 billion. No one truly has any hope of finding out exactly how that money is going to be spent.
What I thought I would do this morning in the few minutes that are allowed to me is to put myself in the shoes of Canadians who, after Monday afternoon, might want to have some notion of what is happening to them. I wonder what the unemployed in this country are thinking.
Where do they believe $160 billion is going to go and how is it going to affect them? What about the farmers of this country, many of whom were here in the last couple of weeks telling us how concerned they are about their future? What about the woods workers where the forestry industry which is totally depressed across the country because of the over-valued Canadian dollar?
What about the thousands of men and women in the fisheries, most of whom are in the fishery directly on the seas and in the fish plants? I wonder what they thought was in the budget document and now in the estimates that is going to help them out. Where are the adjustment programs that we heard so much about? Reams of documents were produced on the free trade agreement and people were going across the country. There were blue ribbon commissions put in place to determine programs that would assist workers who were being displaced.
One and a half million people in this country have to be very concerned about the fact that for them, $160 billion will bring them nothing. It is nearly inconceivable because for most people in this country it is an amazing exercise that the government comes forward and politicians from all political parties talk about $1 billion casually.
There has been a great deal of talk recently about testing in our school system. I wonder if anyone at the high school, cegep, community college or university level would like to ask some of the people in the economics classes what a billion dollars is put another way. How many $10 bills is it? How many $100 bills would there be in a billion dollars? How many thousand dollar bills would there be in a billion dollars? If there were such a thing, how many million dollar bills would there be in a billion dollars?
We sit around and we talk about these huge amounts of money as if we really understood. We produce 80 documents and we have a situation where I as a member of public accounts-and I am sure it is an experience shared by many of my colleagues- have been told that senior bureaucrats say that parliamentarians do not use the very voluminous documents that the President of Treasury Board made available to us today. That is the truth. We do not use those documents because we really cannot get to the bottom of them. It is a morass, it is a maze.
We have even been told that people who come to work in departments with a financial vocation are told not to worry too much for a couple of years when they first get there. No matter how well trained they are, with masters in economics and masters in business administration, or even doctorates, do not get frustrated; it will take a couple of years to catch on. They are in a niche, where
February 27, 1992

they are dealing with some very restricted kinds of information.
We are asking small business entrepreneurs in this country to take a look at the estimates and take a look at the budget and try to figure out what is in it for them. We are asking the people, the men and women and the small business operators who have gone bankrupt by the thousands in the last few years, to look at $160 billion and see if there is anything in it for them.
I think all there is in it really is more frustration for the people who cannot get a clue as to what is in these kinds of numbers for ordinary Canadians. We do not know whether there is improper or unauthorized spending. We do not know where the waste is unless we stumble on it. The duplication is sometimes obvious but it is protected in turf wars. There is poor productivity. The Auditor General is very concerned about productivity. He keeps referring to it.
There is a lack of accountability. There may even be some corruption. There are certainly questionable accounting and reporting systems. There is bad management. There are so many things that we could question. When we are talking about an organization that spends $160 billion a year and has well over 200,000 employees, we recognize that it cannot be simple to account for the expenditures of government.
What I am asking and what I hope the President of Treasury Board understands is that as we move toward Public Service 2000, we understand that very few people can cope with the kind of information that is made available to us. We are told by the senior managers that Parliament and the Canadian public are provided with all the information they can use. But that is not true. We are provided with more information than we can use. Is that a purpose that is set out as an objective to make sure that we are overwhelmed, both as parliamentarians and as Canadians, to a point where we really cannot in any way, shape or form deal with the kinds of questions that should be fairly easy for people to get answers to? I want to make sure that we understand how complex the system is. I go back to this example. We have situations, if I can digress for just a moment. I could not help myself.
This morning I picked up The Globe and Mail. Liberals still read The Globe and Mail. You sometimes have to
Routine Proceedings
wonder why. The hon. Minister of Communications asks if we read. Yes, we do, unlike some of his colleagues who are not very fussy about Canadian literature.
This week, as a matter of fact in the March edition of The Globe and Mail report on business, there is a very glowing account of what appeared to be a success story. We are talking about a very sophisticated organization that is Canadian-wide in terms of its input and its ability to assess the economy, and so forth, but also one that has people who are first-rate-researchers, economists- who work for The Globe and Mail and who prepare their business reports, their inserts that we see month to month. Here is March 1992. This is a little bit of a futuristic look as far as The Globe and Mail is concerned. Here is the headline: "The Dean of Discount: With a push from master merchant Dean Muncaster, Bargain Harold's is cashing in as discount retailing goes mainstream."
This is what Canadians are reading this week that came out of The Globe and Mail on the weekend in its report on business.
This morning, in the very same week, this is the headline in the report on business in The Globe and Mail: "Bargain Harold's seeking protection from creditors".
The point I am trying to make here is certainly not that Mr. Muncaster did not have a great success and worked very hard for Canadian Tire. I know many Canadian Tire retailers in this country. I know what a great organization that is. The point I make is that economic analysts and people who are responsible for much of the business information that is disseminated in this country are unable to look at a company like Bargain Harold's and get a grasp of what this economy is doing to a company like that that is Canada-wide.
How can it be expected that ordinary Canadians understand what is happening with their government when we are spending $160 billion a year? It is so complicated that in the documents released by the Treasury Board president today, we cannot find out how many people work for the government. It is incredible. I have asked in public accounts to take a snapshot on any given day, a day ago or two years ago, and tell us how many human beings worked for the Government of Canada on that day. We know that most people who

February 27, 1992
Routine Proceedings
work expect to get a cheque. The system works well enough in that respect. People who work for the government get a cheque. Because of jargon and all kinds of systems, we are unable to determine exactly how many people are on the payroll of the Government of Canada, in other words being paid by the taxpayers of Canada.
It is interesting. If you look at the new approach that will be used by the government, this year 28,000 were removed from Treasury Board control. They went into a special program, a pilot project system that is being used to implement PS 2000 in the next couple of years.
What happens is that the PS 2000 approach and this de-control means that you look at some departments and there is nobody there in terms of person-years. Person-years is an approach that has been used for many, many years.
The ordinary Canadian who would look at the estimates that came out today and who would focus, for example, on the Prime Minister's Office, would find that no one works in the Prime Minister's Office. Nobody works there at all. Zero. This is the kind of thing that goes on. The point I am trying to make is how do you expect Canadians to have confidence that their tax dollars are being well spent and, as important, that their tax dollars are being accounted for when we are going through these exercises where some people are controlled, some people are de-controlled and you do not know how many people are working for you on any given day. Now, in a place like the Prime Minister's Office, nobody works at all.
I want to make one last point on this because somebody might think that we are playing politics with this. The Auditor General of Canada and the Comptroller General of Canada are the two most senior accounting segments in our system of government and this is the situation we are faced with. I quote the Auditor General: "I have unfortunately concluded that the 1991 financial statements do not report certain important elements of information reliably". He could not accept the accounting procedures of the Government of Canada.
We sat in public accounts and tried to get to the bottom of this. Last year, the government fudged the books to a point that it was able to deal with a $2 billion deficit on the basis of the zero and three freeze. It was able to get $1.3 billion out of that. It should have charged
it out over a 13-year period forward because there will be savings in the pay-out of pension plans over the next 13 years.
Petro-Canada, because of an evaluation mistake made in the early 1980s, there is a loss there. Instead of writing it off in the year in which the loss was discovered, it took that back to 1984. It is very creative accounting.
The Auditor General does not agree with that. What do we have? We have the Comptroller General saying that it is perfectly all right. The very sad part of all of this is that both of these individuals rely on accepted accounting practices that have been set out by people who have an interest in public sector accounting.
We had J. J. Kelly come in, a recognized expert on pension plans. We had Joseph Weinstock come in and talk to us. Imagine what chance Canadians have of getting any kind of information from the estimates when the two senior accountants in government, the Auditor General and the Comptroller General, cannot agree on $2 billion as to whether or not it should have been used last year to reduce the deficit. That is the kind of problem faced by Canadians.
We need clarity in our accounting system. We need sense being applied to how we are going to deal with these issues because Canadians want to know what is happening to their $160 billion.

subsubtopic: MAIN ESTIMATES, 1992-93 EXPLANATORY STATEMENT BY PRESIDENT OF THE TREASURY BOARD
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, what we have received today, as the previous speaker suggested, is a great deal of detail which fills out the budget package which was presented on Tbesday by the Minister of Finance.
I think some of the comments which the previous speaker has made are important comments, but I think it is crucial in this brief preview of a debate which will take place on estimates throughout the year, to put very clearly the differences in substance which we have with the approach which the government has taken in the way it has decided to spend its money.
In the days when life was easy for the Liberals in government and they could simply feel they could borrow money and spend it as they wished, perhaps one did not have to look so carefully at where money was spent, but in these days, in these days where, I think, across the country all responsible governments are
February 27, 1992

recognizing that you have to look veiy carefully at how you spend your money, where you make your allocations to see to it that you get fairness for people to see to it that you get results for the economy, it is crucial there be a careful examination of where money is being spent, how it is being reallocated.
We received this great mass of material one hour and a half before the minister stood up to speak this morning. This is not going to be a definitive detailed judgment on these points, but there are certainly some major problems with the reallocations and the expenditures which this government has put before the House this morning.
As we look at this set of estimates, they seem to us to show a government which is still, in the way it allocates its money, very heartless to many people in the country, a government which is still not being as honest as it should in telling Canadians what is happening to their money and a government which is being unfair in the way in which money is being reallocated within the structure of expenditures.
Let me just go through a number of points which I think illustrate why we come to this conclusion that the estimates tabled today demonstrate heartlessness, lack of honesty and unfairness. We take, first, I think the most important reallocation which is in these estimates, the area of expenditure to get people back to work. I do not think there is anyone in this House who does not believe that the fundamental function of us as the Parliament of Canada should be to see to it that we get as close as we possibly can to getting everybody who wants a job back to work. It requires training expenditure. It requires help to companies to train people. It requires help to provinces to be able to develop their training programs.
Yet what has been cut most dramatically in this particular set of estimates? There is no question that it is the estimates of the employment department of this country.
Take, for instance, grants for employment purposes. These are not grants for make-work jobs. I quote from the estimates: "to assist individuals to improve their employability and to promote employment opportunities by assisting local entrepreneurial development". Everybody believes in that. Yet what has this government
Routine Proceedings
done? It has reduced those grants from $127 million last year to under $90 million this year.
If we take contributions they are not meant for make-work jobs either. These are contributions for the provision of training. I am quoting again from the estimates: "for the provision of training, work experience, for mobilizing community resources, for establishing adjustment measures necessary for the efficient functioning of the Canadian labour market". These are all crucial to a good economy in this country. Yet what has happened? These contributions were $1,319,000,000 last year. These have been reduced this year by almost one-quarter of a billion dollars to $1,064,000,000. In total, if we take both grants and contributions, we see a decrease from $1.33 billion to $1.07 billion.
This is unforgivable when there are so many people out of work across this country. We find the money to give tax breaks that benefit manufacturing companies and to give new tax loopholes which the large corporations in this country will be able to take advantage of. Yet we do not find it possible to keep even the same level of funding for employment and training programs as there was in last year's budget. It is unforgivable.
Then there is the question of defence. The Minister of Finance suggested, when he made his speech the other day, that Canada was going to enjoy a peace dividend. When one gets into the estimates one finds there is no reduction in defence expenditure. Looking at the estimates for last year and comparing them with the estimates for this year, one finds that there has been an increase of $230 million in expenditure on defence. So much for the honesty of this government. We have not seen defence cuts. We have seen defence increases.
The government will come back and say: "Yes, but we have spent more money than that in last year's estimates because of the gulf war". But how much more was spent? We were told by officials this morning that the extra expenditure for the gulf war was $147 million. That means that the increase in defence expenditure, even taking the gulf war into account, is almost $100 million from last year to this year. We could not possibly have a clearer case of smoke and mirrors from a government trying to persuade Canadians that they were cutting defence when they were increasing expenditures on defence in this country. This is despite the fact that the cold war is over and we do not need to be putting the tremendous sums of money into defence which were

February 27, 1992
Routine Proceedings
required when it looked like a potential for world war might still exist.
In addition to those two key areas I want to talk a little bit about regional development because it is another area that is important to economic growth in this country. Yet what has happened to the regional development budget in Atlantic Canada for instance? It has been cut. If we look at the budget for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency grants and contributions, they have decreased from $288 million last year to $274 million this year.
If we look for loans to Cape Breton which is one of the hardest hit parts of this country we see a reduction in loans as well. The over-all contribution to regional development in Atlantic Canada has been cut from $357 million to $334 million. This is despite the fact that an economic catastrophe has just hit Atlantic Canada in the fisheries. Again, it is unforgivable, heartless and unfair.
There are some other small points that I want to note that seem to indicate to me that the government has been unfair and heartless in making its cuts in this budget. It has taken one of the very best agencies that we have to help poor people in the less-developed countries, the International Development Research Centre, and it has cut its budget by $8 million. What possible sense can there be in that? It has taken the Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions, which under the new Bank Act has been given more responsibilities, and has reduced its operating budget.
Everybody in this House had heard horror stories about the Immigration and Refugee Board because it cannot do its job fast enough. Has the government given any extra resources to that board? Not a bit.
At the same time this government continues to waste money. It has increased the budget of the Canada 125 exercise by 50 per cent. This is an exercise which is caught up in extreme difficulties and which has no accountability to this House. It is a wasteful way to spend money.
At the same time it is spending extra money, $18 million, to establish a GST centre in the country. This is another expenditure for this bad tax which should be done away with.
I will finish with this point. Perhaps the biggest problem with these estimates is that there is nothing to explain to Canadians the money which is being given to corporations and to wealthy Canadians in tax expenditures and tax reductions which go to help those large corporations. We have mentioned some of them in the House: the fact that a large company can deduct escort services for its business executives, the fact that the capital gains tax of $100,000 which goes strongly to rich individuals is not even costed out in these estimates.
If we want a true picture of where the government is giving its benefits, we need these tax expenditures put clearly before this House.
I want to say however that there is one good thing in this set of estimates that has come before us, one excellent allocation of funding. This excellent allocation of funding is a very significant increase in the budget for the office of the Chief Electoral Officer. The Chief Electoral Officer has been given an increase of $15 million for this year to run an election. I hope that it turns out that election is held and we get rid of this heartless, dishonest and unfair government.

speechtext: The hon. member for Broadview-Greenwood has 13 minutes remaining for debate.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity speak in this budget debate.
I want to start my remarks by going back to last night. It was funny because I became a little bit uptight with the direction of this debate and I momentarily lost control with respect to my colleague from Carleton-Charlotte. I want to take that back. I hope he will accept my apology.
I have watched this Minister of Finance, not just in the last three years, I watched him when I worked on the Hill from 1980 to 1984. Quite frankly I think he is one of the hardest working members of Parliament we have in this House.
Sometimes when I am in my riding people will ask: "What is the Minister of Finance like?" I tell them that I think this is a man who is quasi-monastic in his commitment to public life. I have watched this man day in and day out work long hours. I know he is totally committed to his job and is doing the best he can with the resources he has.
I asked myself last night why I felt so uncomfortable with this budget. Why do I feel that it really is not addressing some of the fundamental issues, not for the advantaged people in our community but for the disadvantaged. The government will say that the fundamentals are in place and it continues to go back to the inflation number which is the lowest in 20 years. I acknowledge that.
As I said last night and I want to repeat today, there is a tremendous cost to the ratchet it has put on inflation in
The Budget
this country. The cost to the nation is the large number of people who are unemployed and the large number of people who are on welfare. They face a budget which really does not have a lot of hope in it.
When the member for Essex-Windsor talked earlier today about estimates relating to training and retraining, he mentioned the fact that when we discuss productivity, competitiveness and education, we have cut the retraining and grants to re-employment by almost $300 million. Those are not hopeful signals we are sending out to this country when we are going through such difficult times.
I ask myself again why I have such a different feeling toward this budget and this Minister of Finance. The bottom line is that I have a different vision of what the national government is all about. I have watched this government for the last few years. It has used the words "streamline" and "restructure". I prefer to use the words "the retreat from national government" or "the diminished federal presence". This government continues to pursue a diminished federal presence in nearly everything it touches.
I want to suggest to the government that it is really putting itself into a position where there is going to be very little to govern here in the direction it is heading.
I want to be very specific and relate this diminished federal presence, not just to the province of Quebec, because we all talk about the diminished federal presence in the province of Quebec and how harmful that will be in galvanizing us as a nation, but I would like to make the point in relation to my own province, the province of Ontario.
As this government reduces its federal presence in those programs which it has had traditional responsibility for, not only is this national government's ability to cope weakened by the serious problems we are facing today, but a situation is created where a premier, such as we have in the province of Ontario, an NDP premier who, by his actions, is filling that void and is developing policies which are exacerbating the unemployment in this country. He is exacerbating our ability to be competitive.
Here we have the premier of Ontario who, within two or three years, will actually have more economic power than the national government. The province of Ontario will have more spending power than the national government. Is that really what we want?

The Budget
By diminishing that federal presence then the person who is operating that program, such as the premier of Ontario, will fill the void that the national government runs away from and, in the process of doing that, we will lose our ability to give direction or have say because he who pays the piper calls the tune.
Right now, when this government talks about reducing the deficit, trying to tell Canadians it is trying to control the debt, most of that reduction is coming to them because of the reduced federal presence.
Do you know what is going to happen, Mr. Speaker? We are going to have a situation, as we diminish this federal presence, where those regions of our country who do not have the ability to provide the economic thrust to maintain national standards, whether it be in education or in any other phase of our economy, are going to be at a disadvantage.
When I was elected in my community I was asked to come here to speak for a strong national government, a national government that would look out for the disadvantaged regions of this country, a government that would make sure that those standards were national. This budget is really working against that principle. It is a retreat from the national government and it is pushing more and more responsibilities to the provinces.
Mr. Speaker, you signalled me that my time has lapsed. I hope that more members of Parliament, who are from the disadvantaged regions of this country, see through this budget and understand that is where it is taking us.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as the member alluded, last evening we were engaged in debate in the House. We were the last two speakers to be on last night, and I am glad that I have the opportunity to respond to the member this morning.
I go back to a comment that the member made this morning. I think there is some commonality of thought here, although I am sure it is not complete. He talks about the tremendous cost of getting the fundamentals correct in this country. By that of course we are taking a look at interest rates at the lowest they have been in 20 years, inflation the lowest it has been in 20 years and so on. We do not have the time to go through all of those
obviously. We know that we have paid a cost for that. I think we all acknowledge that. At the same time we acknowledge that it is important to get those fundamentals correct for investment to take place in this country to get us on the course of recovery which I believe that we are on this point.
What is the cost in the long term of not getting the fundamentals correct? We acknowledge the fact that we paid a price for that on one side, but in the long term, what is the real cost of not getting those correct? When we have runaway inflation, interest rates that are over 20 per cent as they were 10 years ago, could the member please comment on that aspect of it?

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the question. It is a good question. I think it is a question of balance. If you are almost six months ahead of your inflation targets, your interest rates are the lowest that they have been in almost 20 years, and you are still getting signals that this is not sparking confidence in the economy, that this is not getting a reaction from the 1.7 million entrepreneurs in this country who are our greatest hope for job creation, and I am not talking about make work projects here, when you are getting the feeling from these people that their confidence is so fragile that they are not striking out, that they are not investing, that they are not hiring, I suggest that the government has to loosen that ratchet a little bit. It has room. It has room in the interest rates. It has room with respect to inflation.
I am not saying we should have a spending binge here, but to have a $300 million cutback on retraining when we are all talking about retraining and global competitiveness, there is enough slack in the inflation numbers here that we could have handled that.
I want to suggest one other thing regarding the Small Business Loans Act which in the minister's budget doubled from $100,000 to $200,000.1 think that is good. My problem with it is that if you want to get confidence and you want to get that 1.7 million entrepreneurs sparked and going, if each one of them will hire one person, unemployment is gone and we are back in business and then we can really attack that deficit. That, to me, is one area of the minister's budget that he should be buying full-page ads with. He should be taking taxpayers' money and he should be communicating to the 1.7 million entrepreneurs that this facet of the budget exists.
February 27, 1992

I say to all hon. members here that 99 out of 100 small businessmen do not know what that Small Businesses Loans Act is all about. I challenge the government to communicate it to all Canadian businessmen.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in his remarks the member covered an awful lot of ground. He also alluded in his closing remarks to the fact that the government was transferring to the provinces and to the individuals an awful lot of hot potatoes in terms of training and development, for example.
I want to refer to the estimates that were tabled this morning and ask the member this: In the Main Estimates for Employment and Immigration we find that there is a net decrease of $177 million in employment. I was wondering if job training, job creation, is not something that we should address more thoroughly.
I notice also that in the transfer payments to the provinces and to the agencies, the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency, for example, is cut by $13.4 million. There is a whole series of cuts to programs which, indeed, could be used or could have been used to create employment. I want to ask the member if he could elaborate on his views as to how we could use these moneys to put people to work.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I thank the member for his question. The training cuts are a mystery to me and, quite frankly, I wonder if the reason why the government seems to be retreating from this training section is linked to the constitutional talks where we are talking about putting more training into the hands of the provinces. If that is the case, I am very nervous because I think that is something the national government should maintain a direct linkage with and the ability to give direction to.
The businessmen of downtown Toronto came out with the statement yesterday that a lot of them supported this minister's budget. Quite frankly, I am mystified, I am at a loss as to why they are supporting it. If they are just supporting it on the fact that the number crunching side of it is good, fine, I have acknowledged that. But combined in a budget there should be some innovation, there should be some creative ideas, especially in the area of training and retraining, a topic which all the businessmen are talking about. In that particular area I
The Budget
am absolutely convinced that if you asked those businessmen if they want support for training and retraining- which is in a sense a capital investment-I am sure once they are aware that this government has cut back on training, they are going to reverse their position.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I know the time for questions is just about over. I certainly listened with interest to the thoughtful remarks, as they usually are, by the hon. member for Broadview-Greenwood.
There are many things to say. I certainly share how he started his remarks this morning in terms of trying to distinguish and separate the feeling and respect that one has for a fellow colleague, especially the Minister of Finance, in his monastic drive to be a real public servant, helping the public good and the land, and being a little critical or adding questions, or introducing questions, on the budget that that minister presented. I certainly share those views because of a long relationship with the Minister of Finance.
I, too, have serious questions about aspects of the budget and I would like to ask the member specifically this: I think really the thought of a businessman downtown may be partly what I call sort of a Stockholm syndrome to the budget. First you have the personality of the minister, who is very warm, engaging and human. Then you have a lot of bad news that has permeated the economic scene and/or the land for so long that a budget that has some glimmer of creativity makes us all feel a little good. I think we are all in that sort of mood.
In terms of something that I really find difficult that happened-and there is an argument about how much show it was and how much reality it was-is the elimination of some of these agencies that do have a national focus, that have helped the land, especially in these difficult times. I am thinking specifically of the Science Council of Canada and the Economic Council of Canada.
I would like to ask this member a question. The time for questions is short. I have many questions I could put to him but I am going to try to get questions to some of the government ministers if they stand some time during this debate in view of some of the history around here at the creation of the Economic Council of Canada.

February 27, 1992
The Budget
In terms of the $22 million that I guess has been saved with the elimination of these 14 agencies and the merger of these other agencies and commissions, how does the member, with his experience in politics and in the outside world, balance that specific reduction of $22 million with all those agencies and all the difficulties that is going to create in eliminating the Science Council of Canada and the Economic Council of Canada when in effect the government, up until now, on just five different areas, has spent over $125 million. Be it the Spicer commission, the commission on reproductive technology, the royal commission on transportation, the Minister of Industry, Trade and Commerce competitive strategy, all of these are $20 million plus. I just wonder if he feels-and it may be a leading question-this is going to instil confidence in Canada and Canadians in the way we are going.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I thank the member for Annapolis Valley-Hants for the question.
First of all, a lot of those agencies were set up by Liberal governments. The purpose of those agencies was to provide policy ideas, policy suggestions. It is impossible when you are a politician to come up with the ideas yourself. You go to an independent organization. Quite often those organizations, even when we were in power, did not always agree with us. They criticized us. They were there to probe and spark debate and to inspire. From that point of view, I think the government is being shortsighted, but I do want to give the government a little bit of credit for something here.
The Economic Council of Canada, and I was reading one of their documents last night, "A Joint Venture: The Economics of Constitutional Options", produced a lot of good stuff. I think that when the Economic Council of Canada produced that paper saying that it was not such a bad thing for Quebec to be a sovereign nation, quite frankly, had I been the Prime Minister, that day I would have called the directorship of that operation in and I would have said: "Listen, we have got enough problems with unity in this country as it is. You are not politicians and it is not your job to promote the fact that it is an easier way to live in this country as a divided nation than a united nation". On that specific point, I think the Economic Council of Canada was way off base.
I think we are absolutely crazy to abolish the Science Council of Canada and a lot of those other agencies. I do not know all of them, but I know a lot of them have good, honest, hard-working people and I think that the government was penny wise and pound foolish.

speakeroldname: Mr. Pierre H. Vincent (Parliamentary Secretary to Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Finance
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I spent all day yesterday in the House, listening to the comments of my colleagues on this side, but mostly to the comments of the opposition.
This is my eighth budget and my seventh budget as Parliamentary secretary to the Minister of Finance. In all those eight years I never heard a single constructive comment or suggestion from the opposition when it was discussing the budget. I think this shows something very important is lacking in this House. Criticism should be constructive and we should also consider the budget for what it is.
I am getting rather tired of hearing the opposition complain there is no education policy in the budget, no social policy or cultural policy or health policy. A budget is a budget. In the private sector, a budget shows columns of figures, with the bottom line indicating whether the year's results were positive or negative. That is a budget. As far as policies are concerned, we have ministers who announce policies as appropriate to their individual budgets. The same applies to the private sector. When I look at a private company's budget, there is an operations sector. There is someone in charge of operations and someone in charge of sales. The person in charge of sales has a budget to spend and defines policy in terms of what is best for the company. We have to stop expecting the budget to contain all the government's policies in every sector. That is not what a budget is for.
I think it is time this was understood. The Minister of Finance gives us his budget forecast, explains what the monetary situation is and where we are headed. He defines a few broad principles. The purpose of the budget is to give Canadians a financial statement they can trust, not 48 policies.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
What about hope?
February 27, 1992

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Finance
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
The hon. member mentioned hope. In fact this budget is a budget of hope. I would like to get back to the tax changes announced in the budget, because when we talk about revenue and expenditures, we have to talk about the Income Ihx Act. That is where the money comes from, and that is where less money will be coming from when we amend this act.
What the budget tells us, is how the money comes in and how much it will cost to run the country. That is what the budget is about.
The budget deals strictly with the fiscal aspect and how it will affect taxpayers. People should stop saying that there is nothing in the budget for this or that program. We had a good example only 10 minutes ago, when the Minister of Communications tabled a new bill. This bill was not part of the budget because it is the responsibility of the Department of Communications. It is about communications policy, and it was tabled by the Minister of Communications.
I hope the opposition will take these comments to heart and will start offering some constructive criticism, without trying to make the budget into something it is not.
I would like to give a short history of Canada's financial situation since 1984 when we were elected. You will recall that in 1984, the government spent $39 billion more than it was getting in revenue. This year the deficit will be $31 billion and next year it will be $27 billion. We have managed to reduce the current deficit every year, but this does not deal with the problem of the national debt. In 1984 the national debt was $206 billion. The opposition will say that today it is nearly $400 billion and that it is all our fault.
When we talk about the national debt, we must remember to include the interest charges this government has to pay on the debt it inherited from the Liberal government. The interest charges since 1984 total $239 billion-

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext: Highway robbery.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Finance
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext: -which corresponds exactly to the debt we inherited in 1984.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext: Outrageous.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Finance
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
However we managed to have an operating surplus which means that this year, if we exclude the interest charges payable, the government is spending less
The Budget
money than it raises. We are now operating like the average family. We are not borrowing with MasterCard to pay chargex, as was the case under the former Liberal government.
That is where we were in 1984 and we must continue in that direction. To do so, again, we must take difficult measures and make cuts. I heard my opposition colleagues talk about the 46 agencies that were cut. When a family, a business or an individual cannot afford to do something, what do they do? They do not do it. Here we had the habit of borrowing when we could not afford something. That is over. If we cannot afford something we do not borrow, we cut.
That is exactly what Canadians want. They understand, because they pay enough tax to understand that the government cannot borrow any more. Every day, we hear members opposite get up-and we should count how many times they do, it would be hilarious-and ask questions in order to obtain more money. They do not understand what Canadians want. For example, take an open-line show in my riding of Trois-Rivieres yesterday at noon, from 11.30 to 1.30, when the question was: Are you for or against the Hon. Don Mazankowski's budget? Seventy per cent of the callers said they were in favour of this budget. Seventy per cent supported it on an openline show in Trois-Rivieres.
People want us to run the country as they handle their family budget. The fiscal measures announced in the budget also reflect what Canadians want. This budget was prepared by the Minister of Finance after consulting the national caucus, the Quebec caucus and MPs. Members come back from their ridings on Monday morning and know, after spending the weekend with their constituents, just what Canadians want. People in Ottawa don't understand the problems of Abitibi-the member for Abitibi does. The same goes for Trois-Rivieres and every riding.
You will hear people say that the announcement about RRSPs is a smoke screen, I was not greatly in favour of the original request to let people use their RRSPs to buy their first home, because I thought that it would not have the intended effect. People who do not have a house surely do not have much money in their RRSPs and are just starting out in their life and career. This is for the purchase of a principal residence, so someone can take

February 27, 1992
The Budget
$20,000 out of his or her RRSP and use the money to pay for an existing home or one that they want to build and so on. For a married couple, each partner can take $20,000, which makes a $40,000 down payment. That is excellent, and it will make a valuable contribution to real estate and the buying and selling of homes. It must be seen in that light and the program must be used in that way.
Some will tell you that it does not pay, because the $20,000 in your RRSP was not subject to income tax and you will lose that advantage. That is a good point. On the other hand, if I borrow $20,000 from a financial institution, I will have to pay interest every year on this loan, say $2,000 at 10 per cent, but I will have to earn $2,500 or $3,000 before tax to pay my income tax and also the interest on the loan and even more to gradually pay off the principal.
I submit that this plan can be very profitable for those who use it wisely. It will enable them to buy either a first home or one that better suits their needs in 1992, and that, again, at a very interesting price.
This echoes the wishes expressed by Canadians. In my riding, many real estate agents and others have written to me. They said: "Let us use them." Provincial premiers had also mentioned something along that line.
Another issue I have received a lot of correspondence about is that of the treatment of common law couples. That too can be found as a new tax measure in the budget. From now on, common law couples will be treated the same as married couples under the Income Tax Act and for the purposes of the GST and other credits, transfers and so on. That is what happens when a caucus sets its shoulder to the wheel and incorporates suggestions in preparing a budget.
This particular measure had been long-awaited in my riding of Trois-Rivieres, as in the rest of the province of Quebec and Canada. Not only is this part of an improved tax legislation but it also reflects the social and economic reality of 1992. It should be pointed out that this is not a family oriented policy or anything like that, but an amendment to tax laws and, as such, it was included in the budget.
Another new feature in this budget is the $100,000 capital gains exemption. We know that every Canadian man and woman was already entitled to a $100,000 capital gains exemption. The budget does not take it away. We figured that, in order to assist and stimulate the Canadian economy, that exemption should apply specifically to gains on active revenue-producing assets. This does not mean-just this morning, I was reading a piece about investment property in La Presse-Xhai the real estate market will shrink. It means that you can, as individuals, decide to invest say in a rental property, realize gains on it every year and, when you sell it, you will be taxed less because it will be considered as a capital gain.
Now if you decide not to invest in real estate but rather in an company operating in the Trois-Rivieres riding, which I hope is what you would chose, when you sell your shares your active participation in that business creates jobs and generates employment. The $100,000 exemption on capital gains will still be valid. Compare this to real estate which does not create jobs. If you buy a four-unit apartment building you will not employ somebody full time for its maintenance.
Therefore nobody is penalized. Each Canadian can chose where he or she will invest. Evidently we all know that there is a higher risk involved in a small business than in a four or eight-unit apartment building.
I feel that this is one way our government is looking at the economic reality of Canada. It is an incentive for all small business owners who often must seek are out investors, who often need small sums like $50,000 or $100,000 to carry on more securely, to buy new equipment, to get the technology they want and so reach the national level.
Incidentally, talking about small businesses, another measure which will be helpful for our businesses is the raising of the maximum from $100,000 to $200,000 for small business loans. I think that doubling the amount a small business is entitled to borrow. Mr. Speaker, you are signalling me that I have only two minutes left, but I feel I have just begun. I will speed up a bit. I was saying that allowing small businesses to borrow $200,000, guaranteed by the government, is another positive step taken by this government to assist our businesses and help the
February 27, 1992

The Budget
economy. Another measure designed to help our businesses is the program allowing a small or medium-sized company to borrow money, while the loan and revenues made on that loan by the lender will be considered a dividend rather than an interest. As we all know, if these companies expand, they will create employment. If they create employment, it will benefit the Canadian economy.
In conclusion, I would like to congratulate the Minister of Finance who suggested the merging of three programs for children into just the one. People will receive only one cheque per month, not taxable and bigger than what they used to get. There will less paper burden and everybody will therefore be happier. Instead of having three programs, there will only be one: one cheque per month, and bigger than what people now get. This must not go unnoticed because unfortunately I do not often hear the opposition mention the positive measures that are in the budget. The deficit is reduced and people have tax policies that meet their needs. These things must be said. We must be positive. That is how the regional economy of Trois-Rivieres, of Quebec and of Canada will improve.
In concluding, I would also like to emphasize the fact that, for the first time in a very long time, the Minister of Finance has reduced taxes for all Canadians. Yet the opposition will automatically say: "Not by much, not by much". That is not the point. The point is that thanks to the cuts made in the last eight years, thanks to the work of the member for Etobicoke Centre and now the member for Vegreville and thanks to the fact that for the last eight years Canadians throughout the country have tightened their belt in terms of federal expenses, this government has been able to reduce taxes.
Everyone in this House would love it if there were no taxes, if there was no GST. We all agree on that. It is perhaps the only thing on which we all agree, but we agree on that. However, because of our structures and programs, we must have and we must pay taxes. From that point on, this government has demonstrated that you can increase taxes, but it has also shown that you can reduce them. Again I want to congratulate the Minister of Finance in that regard.
My time is up but I would just like to ask all members to be positive and to make sure that this budget is passed as quickly as possible.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have listened with interest to the hon. member.
One of the comments he made was that the budget was to put trust and confidence in the people. I agree that that is what a budget should do but certainly we have not seen any initiatives in this budget that would put any trust or confidence back in the people.
He went on to say that it is a budget of hope. The same thing applies. I cannot see anything in this budget that offers any hope whatsoever for the 1.5 million people who are unemployed. I know in my province the unemployment rate is approximately 17 per cent.
This budget, as I said, does not offer any hope. There is no capital works program. There is very little investment in research and development. There is nothing new in training initiatives.
He went on and talked about small business and what a great thing that the ceiling of borrowing has been doubled. Does he not realize that small business today is trying to survive? It does not matter if the borrowing level is quadrupled. If they cannot take advantage of it, what good is it?
Look at the bankruptcy rates of small businesses across this country. This government should be doing something for small business. It was small business that helped lead us out of the last recession but the government fails to realize that.
This is the question that I want to ask. I want to come back to the statement the member made about it being a budget of hope. I would like to know what hope this budget offers to the 1.5 million people who are unemployed across this country.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Finance
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I must admit I am disappointed with the question because either the member did not listen to my presentation or they did not understand the message.
At the beginning of my speech, I explained the nature of a budget. A budget is made up of figures, it is not a series of announcements by 40 departments of what is to come during the following year. It presents revenues expenditures and credits for each department. That is what a budget is all about. It is not supposed to describe

The Budget
all government policies for the year to come. Again, the member said the budget did not contain an education policy, a business policy, this or that. That is right, the budget does not present any of those things. The sole purpose of a budget is to allocate funds so that departments may announce their policies and the Canadian economy may adjust to it. The taxation measures are in there.
Maybe my colleague did not read the budget because she says it contains nothing for small businesses while in fact there are five or six taxation measures aimed at small business in that budget. It might be a good idea for her to read it.
I was a tax lawyer in Trois-Rivieres when Marc Lalonde established tax credits for scientific research in his budget.

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext: The theft of the century.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Finance

subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Finance
subsubtopic: FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF THE MINISTER OF FINANCE
speechtext:
Did you notice, Mr. Speaker, how shocked they are when we talk about real life?
Marc Lalonde had written in his beautiful budget that it was going to cost about $200 million. He was Minister of Finance so he just said "about $200 million". Do you know how much it actually costs Canadians? Four billion, including $1.9 billion in fraudulent claims, as the Auditor General pointed out. We spent $4 billion on a tax credit scheme which were to cost about $200 million. I did not say $4 million. I said $4 billion.
He knew it, but he did not do anything to put an end to it. We had to wait until the election of the Progressive Conservative Party and the appointment of the member for Etobicoke Centre as Minister of Finance to do away with that program. The meter was then at $4 billion, including $1.9 billion in fraudulent claims. Could my colleague across the floor imagine what we could do with $4 billion of taxpayer's money, $4 billion which simply disappeared?
Such was the Liberal policy. Unfortunately, they do not understand the budget. They do not understand its philosophy. They just do not understand what a budget is supposed to be.
I notice, that I am out of time.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
